Clearly the poor are finding it much more difficult to access healthcare services, likely due to out of pocket costs.
	In discussing next steps towards improving neonatal and maternal care indicators, the most basic question is how to most effectively address the lack of service.  Specifically, should Indonesia develop program-specific approaches or strengthen the overall health system without focusing on pre and post-pregnancy care for the mother and child.  There is no question that programmatic approaches to solve the problems outlined above are attractive.  Not only do “vertical approaches” that target one sector of improvements have much more targeted, manageable objectives, they also generally generate faster results.  There are some drawbacks to keep in mind, however.  One major drawback is that investing heavily in programming for one particular area of the health sector often means that funding for other areas suffers and human resources will flock towards working in that area that has more resources (the effect of international funding to HIV/AIDS and its effect on the family planning sector is one example).  In addition, running multiple parallel programs for one area results in duplication of services that are also uncoordinated between programs.  This leads to an increase in forms and paperwork for supplies and funding.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
Culture moves through the world like a ghost in the dark, unseen but felt, undefined yet bearing down upon all things. The negotiator knows this truth deep in his bones though he may not speak it. He knows too that culture aint no single thing that can be caught and held in the hand like some creature of flesh and blood. It moves through men like wind through dead trees.

The old ones would tell you that all Russians are this way or all Japanese are that way but they were wrong and had been wrong a long time. A man who sets to bargaining across borders would do well to know the weight of culture bearing down upon the table where the deals are made. When he looks upon foreign ways he sees them through eyes colored by his own raising, like looking through glass stained with the mud of home.

To know another man's culture is to walk in the tracks he's left behind. Study the history written in blood and bone. Accept the prejudices that run deep as groundwater. A negotiator who comes to foreign soil bearing a weak hand must bend like a reed in the wind, must take what he finds and work within its bounds. There aint no changing what centuries have built.

Corporate culture rises up like kingdoms within kingdoms. Some outfits work their people like slaves to the lash while others let them run loose as wild horses. You can read it in how they dress and how they talk, whether they speak straight or crooked, whether they give to the poor or hoard their gold. Even in America where men claim to be free these kingdoms flourish, different as day and night though they share the same soil.

Values run deeper than a dry well. They tell you why a man does what he does, why he'll die before shaming his people or why he'll fight tooth and nail over copper pennies. A smart negotiator learns these things before he ever sets foot in the room where the deals are made. But knowing the lay of the land aint enough. He must know the man across the table like he knows his own brother, must read the truth in his eyes and the lies in his smile. That's the only way to walk out whole.

He sat there in the dim light reading the words again. The fool hath said in his heart there is no God. Words from an old book. Ancient words. Words that Anselm had known and Aquinas too and now here they were again like smoke rising from dead fires.

They were both of them looking for the same thing. God. The God of scripture and testament. Not some other god dreamed up in the minds of lesser men but the true God if there was such. To speak of other gods would muddy the waters and that wouldnt serve. No. Better to stay the course they'd set. Even if neither one had found the whole of it.

Anselm had his way of thinking. Said that God lived in the understanding like blood in the veins. That you could no more think him out of existence than you could think yourself out of breathing. Complex geometries of thought laid out in dead languages. But what it came to was this: that the truth of God was in you already like a thing you'd known but forgot you knew. Didnt need no evidence. Didnt need no proof. Just faith. Dark and deep as wells.

But Aquinas. He was different. Said you could prove God like you could prove fire makes smoke. Through reason. Through the hard facts of the world. Would have been a fine thing for spreading the word. Converting the heathens. No need to take nothing on faith when you could show em plain as day. He had five ways of proving it. Change and cause and necessity. Excellence and the harmony of things. Like looking at a puzzle with one piece gone. You dont need to see the missing piece to know what shape it is. The emptiness tells you. The absence.

He looked at the words again. The fool hath said in his heart there is no God. Ancient and terrible words. True maybe. But neither one of them had got to the heart of it. Not really. Not in full. The truth was bigger than their proofs and darker than their faith and it was still out there waiting. Like something crouched in the dark of the world. Watching. Patient as stones.

Colors speak their own tongue in this world and some men know how to wield them better than others. Fitzgerald was such a man. In that book of his about Gatsby he done something peculiar with the way he painted his world. Like a man who'd found some old photographs bleached by the sun and knew there was truth hidden in their fading. He'd take words that had no business being together and marry them up like some demented preacher. Then he'd grab hold of a color like it was something living and breathing and hed make it mean what he wanted it to mean. Gold and green and white and gray and that bloodstained pink. All of them carrying their own weight like pallbearers at the funeral of meaning.

The white and gray especially. They was like twins born of different mothers. White being the child raised in them fine houses with silver spoons while gray was the bastard cousin left to scratch in the dirt. Fitzgerald he understood this. Every damn page dripping with white like fresh paint. Daisy and that Jordan girl forever wrapped in white like ghosts haunting the edges of the story. Even Nick with his white flannels and Tom in his white shirt like they was all trying to outshine each other in some godless parade. Only time the white gave way was at them parties Gatsby threw where the colors screamed like heathens in a church.

He painted his world white and gray like a man possessed. The canyons of New York white as bone. Them party people's names gone gray as week-old newsprint. Apartment buildings stacked like slices of some endless white cake that nobody'd ever eat. The people themselves wasn't spared neither. Jordan and Daisy with their white childhood like it was something pure when it wasnt. That valley of ashes with its gray cars and gray land stretching out like some biblical wasteland. Even the people there, that Italian child and the old dog-seller, gray as cemetery stones.

Then when he'd loaded them colors up with all the meaning they could bear he turned them loose like weapons. Used them to strip away what was real from what wasnt. Take Daisy. She comes floating back into the story dressed in white, driving that white car like some kind of pale angel. But there wasnt nothing angelic about her. She was just something Gatsby wanted. Something he thought he could possess like you might possess a fine watch or a new suit. That gray fur collar around her neck like a noose. White dress before the showdown with Tom like she was trying to prove something that couldn't never be proved.

Thats what colors do in the hands of someone who knows their power. They tell truths that words alone cant tell.

The county lay blessed by sun and mild days, a thing rare in this world. Fields stretched endless with tomatoes blood red against the earth and citrus trees bent heavy with fruit and the green leaves of countless crops reaching toward heaven. Squash and broccoli and herbs. Peaches soft as a babe's cheek. Lemons yellow as beaten gold. The berries dark and glistening like beads of blood. Honey sweet as sin in glass jars clouded with age.

They called it organic farming and folk would wait months just to taste of it. Eggs and milk pure as they'd been since time was young. Sometimes they'd let people walk the land. Watch the birds. See how things was done. Government men would come too with their papers and their promises, talking about programs and benefits and such.

The land remembered things. Remembered the old ones who'd walked it first. Their footsteps in the dirt like scripture writ in sand. Then came the cattlemen with their herds and the woodcutters with their saws. The land remembered them too.

A hundred and sixty acres it was, pressed up against Cleveland Forest like a child against its mother's breast. Chaparral and grass that didn't belong and oak trees old as sin. The creatures lived there still. Kangaroo rats and yellow-legged frogs and butterflies that danced like spirits in the morning light. The gnatcatcher too, though fewer now than before. Burrowing owls watching with eyes like amber coins.

But the farming wasn't easy. No chemicals to kill the weeds or the things that ate at the crops. Everything done by hand like in the old days. More work. More loss. The big farms had their machines and their poisons but here they did it different. Let the land breathe. Let it live. Planted cover crops and moved the cattle like chessmen on a board. Fought the plants that didn't belong. Sometimes a man would look at his ledger and see red like blood on the page. That's when he'd need help. Help from men in offices with their programs and their promises. Help to keep the land alive and still put food on his own table.

That's how it was in this corner of the world. That's how it had to be.

Brothers carry a bond that runs deeper than blood. A thing that cant be broke nor bent nor burned away. Inside that bond dwells love and pride and jealousy and cruelty and all manner of darkness that men carry in their hearts. Brothers know each other in ways that others cant. When they look upon each other they see themselves reflected back like some dark mirror in a forgotten place. And when the world turns cold and mean thats when the true nature of brotherhood shows itself whether it be good or evil. But such knowledge carries with it a terrible cost.

The boy called Doodle and his brother lived out their days in that lush southern land where the heat lay like a wet blanket and the air was thick enough to drown in. Pride was the brothers constant companion. It rode him like a demon. He'd wanted someone to race with through Old Woman Swamp and to climb the twisted vines that hung there like the beards of dead prophets. Someone to swim with to Horsehead Landing. Someone to perch with him in the highest fork of the ancient pine that stood sentinel behind their barn. But Doodle wasnt made for such things.

The younger brother had come into the world with a heart that beat wrong. Like some broken timepiece marking hours that didnt exist. The doctors said he wouldnt live and if he did hed never run nor jump nor swim like other boys. And this knowledge ate at the older brother like poison. He remembered nights studying the small bundle in the crib and thinking dark thoughts about pillows and silence and how easy it would be. But then Doodle smiled at him one day and that smile carried in it something pure and true that burned away the darkness in his heart. At least for a time.

Their final journey together was marked by thunder and lightning and rain that fell in gray sheets. Pride and disappointment warred in the brothers heart like ancient enemies and in the end only one of them would walk away from that place. Only one would carry the memory of what happened there in the storm and the mud and the crushing weight of what brotherhood truly means.

The mind of man aint nothing if not a dark and tangled wilderness. Time was men thought it simple as marks pressed in wax or words writ upon papyrus sheets but they was wrong about that. Wrong as they was about most things. These days they speak of computers and circuits but even that aint the truth of it. The truth dont live in metaphors.

The world comes at you raw and brutal. Light and sound and heat all hammering at the gates of your skull like armies of the damned. Your brain takes these things, these messengers from whatever godless country lies beyond, and turns them into something else entirely. Something electric. Something alive.

It works two ways, they say. Bottom up and top down like the movement of vultures circling some dead thing in the desert. When your eyes light upon a black shape against white it aint just the borders and the colors that tell you what it is. Your mind already knows boxes. Knows them deep down in whatever primitive hollow such knowing resides.

There's a filter too. Some ancient mechanism that sorts what matters from what dont. Like how you might hear your name called across a crowded room full of nothing but noise and darkness. Your brain processes every blade of grass you ever laid eyes on but that filter, if it works right, keeps you from going mad with the knowing of them.

Memory aint one thing but many. Short and long, sensory and working, all of them different as blood is from bone. Words get stored different ways - by their shape or their sound or their meaning. Some memories, they say, are nothing but electricity running circles through your head like them horses in a desert carnival. Others get pressed into the very proteins of your brain, folded up and put away like old letters in a trunk.

They got models for how all this knowledge gets stored. Scientists and their theories, each one different as the next, all of them probably wrong in their own particular way. One says its like a web, with every piece connected to every other piece. Chair connected to table connected to wood and on and on until everything in the whole world is somehow kin to everything else. But who can say if thats the truth of it. The mind keeps its own counsel and gives up its secrets slow, if it gives them up at all.

The money died in 2007. It died slow and it died hard and when it was done dying there wasnt much left of anything at all. Men stood in lines stretching round buildings like great gray serpents, waiting for work that wasnt there. Houses empty. Banks fallen. The greatest of corporate beasts laid low in the dust and ash of their own making.

The seeds of it were sown in the time of Clinton. He who would be king twice over sought the love of the masses and in doing so loosened the chains that held the money-men in check. A scribe named Holmes wrote of it in the Times. Wrote of how Fannie Mae, that great beast of mortgage and loan, was pressed by men in suits to give money to those who had none. To maintain its hunger for profit. Holmes saw what was coming like a prophet in the waste. Saw the government would have to reach down with its cold hand and save what was left, same as they done before with the savings and loans in the eighties.

They made new kinds of money then. Strange words for strange things. Adjustable-rate mortgages. Mortgage-backed securities. Collateralized debt obligations. Words that meant nothing and everything. Like incantations. Like prayers to dead gods. The money-men wove these things together till you couldnt tell where one ended and another began. Till the whole country was caught in this web of debt and promise.

When it broke it broke hard. The five great houses of investment banking stood with four trillion in debt, near a third of all the nation's worth. Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch sold for pennies. Lehman Brothers died in the street. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley survived but were changed, made to wear the chains of regulation like penitents. Fannie and Freddie, five trillion in debt between them, became wards of the state in the ninth month of 2008. The government took them in like orphans. Like foundlings. But they were not innocent.

The words lay dead on the page like bones bleached in desert sun. No life in them. No blood neither. Just facts piled on facts like the stacked cordwood he'd seen as a boy, waiting for the fire that would consume them all.

He studied the page before him. The way of telling tales aint to tell them at all, his father had said once. Show em the truth of things. The weight and heft. Let em feel the raw heart of it beating in their hands.

He thought about exposition. That dark and nameless thing that crept into stories like a thief. Stealing life from words. Draining the blood from tales that ought to pulse with it. Making dead things of living stories.

There was a right way and a wrong way and the difference twixt them was vast as the space between stars. You could say a man was Air Force once and managed a gas station nights and married twice with no young ones to show for it and dreamed of owning that station someday. You could say all that. But it wouldn't show the way his hands still moved like he was touching sky when he walked the empty forecourt at midnight. Wouldn't show how he touched the wedding band he still wore like it was both blessing and curse. Wouldn't show how his eyes went distant when cars pulled in trailing highway dust, like maybe one day it'd be someone he knew from back then. Back when he flew. When he was something else entirely.

The telling of tales was like breaking wild horses. You couldn't rush it. Couldn't force it. Had to let it come natural as breathing. Had to let the story find its own way home.

He looked at the words again. Dead things. No pulse in them. No breath neither. He'd have to start over. Show the truth of things. The weight and the heft. Let them feel the raw heart of it beating in their hands.

He watched the screen flicker in the dark of morning, the news from Columbus casting its pale glow across the room. August thirteenth two thousand and eleven. First came word of Ashley where a man named Hostettler had done his wife with a knife. They showed his face, a darkness in it like something youd see in an old daguerreotype of a murderer. Evil plain as day. Two minutes worth and done.

Then the boy Travis Buyers, eighteen years on this earth and now shot down in Sharon Woods. Critical they said. No arrests. SWAT teams moving through the streets like black beetles. Brief telling, too brief maybe, like they didnt care much for stories about colored folk getting shot. Been that way long as he could reckon. White child goes missing they sound all the bells in christendom but let it be someone with dark skin and silence falls like ash.

Word came of a bullet hole found in one of them flying ambulances. Twenty-two caliber they said. Rifle shot. Money offered for the shooter, five thousand dollars worth of thirty pieces of silver.

Weather man stood there in his suit talking about rain coming. Thunder too. Heat holding in the eighties like it was afraid to leave. Quick tell, wanting folks to stay put and watch more.

Then the UDF robbery down on Clime Road. Dark skinned man they said, wearing a hood like death himself. Six foot tall and lean as a fence post. They went on about his blackness like it was all that mattered in gods creation.

Last came the tale of Rodriguez, some drug lord from Texas moving weed up north like it was cotton in the old days. Three hundred months they gave him. Not twenty-five years mind you but three hundred months like they was counting out each one special. Made sure to say he was Hispanic too, though what bearing that had on anything he couldnt figure. World's got its own way of marking people, he reckoned, whether they ask for it or not.

He sat there studying the papers before him, numbers swimming like black minnows in a dark pool. ETF they called it. Exchange traded fund. Words that meant nothing to the dead world outside but here in this room they held some power still, some echo of the old times when men traded paper for promises and promises for gold.

The figures lay stark against the white sheets. Cold numbers telling cold truths about money and worth and things that no longer existed except in the minds of those who remembered. Ten holdings they showed, top ones they said, making up near sixty-four percent of what they called assets. Assets. As if anything could be held fast in this world.

He thought about diversification. A word from the old world. Like spreading seed across many fields instead of one, hoping some would take root and grow while others withered. The numbers showed it plain as day. The ten-stock portfolio running higher than its parent fund by six point eleven percent. A ghost of better returns haunting the pages. Beta lower by point twelve. Numbers that meant something once, when men still believed in such things.

Standard deviations lined up like prisoners against a wall. Each stock contributing its measure of risk, its portion of uncertainty to the whole. Statistical significance. As if statistics could capture the true nature of risk in a world where everything had already been lost.

The charts stretched out before him like a map of some dead country. IHF they called it, letters that once meant something to someone. Now just marks on paper, telling tales of holdings and returns and measures of things that no longer mattered. Yet he studied them still, like a man reading ancient runes, searching for meaning in the ashes of the financial world.

He thought about the old days when men spoke of sharp ratios and optimal returns. When they believed they could measure risk against reward and find some perfect balance between the two. But he knew better now. Knew that all portfolios, all investments, all carefully laid plans were just dust in the wind. Yet still he ran the numbers. Still he searched for patterns in the chaos. Because that's what men do. They search for order even when they know there is none to be found.

The numbers fell away like dying leaves in that third month. Figure 17 told the tale plain enough and there was no hiding from it. The logs dried up and blew away on the winter wind that swept across that New England campus, taking with it the bicycle riders and the footbound travelers alike. December it was, when the semester draws its last rasping breath and the people scatter to their tasks like blown ash. Grading and schoolwork consuming them whole. The commuter logs forgotten like old photographs in a drawer.

The holiday season came down on them like a shroud. Students and teachers alike vanished into that monthlong darkness, the campus standing empty and cold as a dead church. When they returned in the late January thaw the numbers stayed low, dried up, a riverbed in drought. February brought no relief and none could say why. Perhaps it was the nature of such things, the way fire burns bright then dims to coals and finally to nothing but gray dust. They created what they called the Carpool Challenge Week in March, a desperate flare in the dark, and it drew some back like moths but not enough. Never enough.

They were up against something older than winter, deeper than snow. The American love of the automobile ran in their blood like a fever. Freedom and motion, the wide empty road calling. You could offer a man alternatives but you couldn't make him choose them. They tried with prizes - gift cards for food and drink, for books and comforts. But perhaps they should have gone bigger. A bicycle maybe. Or one of them hybrid cars that run quiet as ghosts. Could have parceled them out slow, like bait. Let the prizes grow month by month until they had something worth killing for. Might have kept them interested. Might have kept them coming back. But they'd never know now. The past was the past and it was written in stone and ash.

He sat there in the dim light of the archive room watching them flicker across the screen one by one, these old Edison pictures, these trick films from the dawn of moving pictures. Fifteen of them all told from 1895 to 1901. Strange ghosts dancing in the darkness, illusions wrought by men long dead who'd spliced together strips of celluloid like witch doctors working their magic.

Most of them followed the old ways. Set-bound pictures they were, shot straight on like some demonic theatre stage, the camera bolted down and immovable as stone. No movement save what danced within the frame itself. Long shots and medium shots was all they knew then. One shot was all they got, one shot was all they needed. But there were others. Others that came later. Others that dared break these ancient laws.

The pictures shared a common blood. Interior sets all of them, framed like some godless proscenium arch where dark things happened. The camera stood mute witness, didnt follow nothing that moved within its gaze. Like vaudeville shows or magic acts, remnants of dead traditions carried forward into this new world. Figures moved sideways like crabs, never toward the glass eye that watched them. He thought of Uncle Josh in that spooky hotel, that old film from 1900. Josh moving back and forth like a prisoner in his cell, never closer, never further, trapped in that two-dimensional hell.

The way they framed it all kept everything at arms length. No close-ups in these demon reels. Theatre folk knew nothing else back then, showed everything at once like God himself watching from above. Actors stayed in their place like good tin soldiers, never daring approach the eye that watched them perform their strange rituals.

Most followed the old rule - one shot one film. Brief little things they were, minute or less depending on how fast they cranked that handle. Not much story to tell in sixty seconds. Just tricks and magic and people appearing and vanishing like smoke. But even then they knew how to lie with pictures. He thought of Mary Queen of Scots, that film from 95. Watched close enough you could see where they stitched together the shots, where they worked their dark magic to make you believe they'd cut off her head right there before your eyes.

These were sorcerer's tools, these first moving pictures. Made by men who knew how to bend light and time to their will. Dead men now, all of them. But their ghosts still danced in the darkness, trapped forever in their silver cage, performing their tricks for empty rooms and forgotten dreams.

The Gothic novel stands as both old and new, a thing caught between worlds like some ancient specter haunting modern halls. Some men praise it and some curse it and some say it has no depth at all while others speak of its terrible power to shake the soul. But they're all wrong and they're all right and that's the way of things.

The first of them was Walpole's Castle of Otranto. He took what was old and made it new again like some dark alchemist working with words instead of metal. The medieval ghosts and the modern ways of telling stories all mixed together in that cursed place he built with ink and paper. Gothic they called it then and Gothic they call it now though the word means something different to every man who speaks it. It was a thing out of time even then. Something that didn't belong. But that's what gave it power.

The old ways of chivalry run through these tales like black veins in marble. Knights and honor and all the things men once held dear but had forgotten. Walpole saw the world around him going dark and godless, the old virtues dying like leaves in winter, and he wrote of better times. Or what he thought were better times. Maybe they never were. But in his mind they stood like ancient towers against a blood-red sky.

You can see it clear as day in how he writes of Frederic. A prince who'd known suffering. A man who'd walked through fire and come out changed. They said the infidels had killed him but death ain't always what we think it is. He was everything a knight should be, everything Walpole thought the world had lost. But even then the writer knew he was painting with colors too bright for this world. Making something that couldn't exist no more, if it ever did.

That's what Gothic is. A dream of something lost. A nightmare of something coming. Both at once and neither one complete. Like watching shadows dance on cave walls and trying to say what makes them move.

They called it supply chain management and it was a thing born of necessity in the year of our Lord nineteen hundred and eighty two when a man named Oliver put words to what had always been. The moving of things through the world. Raw materials to finished goods. Production to customer. All of it connected like the bones of some great beast that stretched across the land.

Six parts made up this beast. Production and supply. Inventory and location. Transportation and information. These were the things that men in suits would use to serve the nameless masses who waited in the dark for their goods.

Production came first like some terrible birth. It was the foundation stone. The bedrock. It determined the when and the where and the how of things made. Men who managed such things needed to know what the masses wanted and they looked to the market like seers reading entrails. The market never lied. It told them what to make and how many and where best to make them. They'd pick their plants careful. Looking for volume and quality like prophets seeking signs in the sky.

He remembered the stores where he'd worked. Walmart. Target. Each had their own scripture. Their own gospel of how things should be. Books that told a man how to dress. How to receive the great trucks that came in the night. It was all written down somewhere. Every detail accounted for like some industrial catechism.

Supply came next. Strategic choices about what could be done inhouse and what needed other hands. Some products were like wandering souls passing through many bodies before they found their final form. Each stop needed different tools. Different skills. Sometimes they'd send the work away to other companies. Outsourcing they called it. A way to keep the velocity. Velocity was their god. The ability to move fast and bend like reeds while keeping the costs low. Always the costs. The numbers written in red in ledgers like the blood of some sacrificial thing.

They had made a religion of it all. A way to move things through the world that was as old as the first trade routes but now had new names. New prophets. New ways to count the cost of everything while knowing the value of nothing.

They was different them Victorian books. All of them filled with their fancy details and lords and ladies and such but there was two that walked a darker path. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights they was called. Something deeper in them books. Something that crawled up out of the dark like some nightborn thing. Made the people in them stories more real somehow. More true.

He remembered the passage bout Oliver. The boy caught between Sikes and Crackit like some small creature trapped between two wolves. Words come at him like shots in the dark. Gunfire and shouts and lights all swirling round in his head while pain ate at him like some hungry thing that wouldnt die. Pain that followed him through the dark like a shadow.

The books they used dreams. Strange visions that come in the night showing what was real and what wasnt. In Oliver's tale these dreams showed what the boy really was inside. What ate at his soul. That shooting scene when it finally come round again in chapter 28 it showed how the boy had no control over nothing. Like a leaf in a river. The pain wasnt sharp no more but stretched out endless like the road ahead. Some unseen hand dragging him away into the dark.

The boy's defeat hung in the air like smoke. Old Fagin had broke something in him. Something that might not never be fixed. Time itself went strange. Day become night become day again. All of it bleeding together in the endless dark. No dawn. No hope. Just the silence eating away at everything until there wasnt nothing left but shadows and pain.

There was a time I minded children at a school. After hours. Teaching them what little I knew. Reading mostly. English too. They sent me a boy called Adrian. Third grade maybe fourth. Something wasnt right with him. The letters on the page they meant nothing to him. Some he knew and others were foreign things. Dark eyes. Dark hair. Latino blood in him sure enough but he spoke English pure as rain.

We went on like that for a time. Then one day his mother came. The others had gone on a trip somewhere and I was watching the ones left behind. She didnt speak no English. Not a word. Just Spanish soft and low like a prayer. My own Spanish was poor but we made do. That's when it hit me like a hammer blow. The boy could read fine enough. Just didnt know our letters is all. Whether that knowledge helped him any I cant say. I hope it did.

I tell this tale because of what it means. Here in California we got children who cant read the tongue they speak in. Aint always clear as you might think. Even a child speaking English pure as spring water might stumble on the written word like it was stones in a creek bed. We all know the problem's there. Question is what to do about it. For Adrian it wasnt so hard. Just needed teaching in the English way of letters. But for them that barely speak English at all its harder. Aint no single answer neither. Dual language. Immersion. Private teaching. ESL. None of these alone will fix what's broke. Got to put them all together like pieces of a broken plate.

The dual language way it's good. Not just for Spanish speakers neither but for all of them. Studies show these children do better than the rest. Some folks fear it. Say it's wasteful. Say most children won't get nothing from it. That aint true. If we was to make it the rule instead of the exception every child would grow stronger for it. But how to do it? Make all teachers speak both tongues? No. That aint possible. But we could have helpers. Special ones who know both languages. Like bridges between two worlds.

From when we're young they tell us there's somethin bigger than us out there in the dark. Somethin we cant wrap our minds around no matter how hard we try. They send you off to learn about it in buildings made of wood and stone where the light comes in through colored glass and makes shapes on the floor like old ghosts. Some take to it natural like breathin while others fight against it like its a tide trying to pull them under. Either way we're all searchin for something to light our way through the dark of this world.

My daddy told me once it was cardinals he liked best. We was sittin on the porch, him and me, smokin cigarettes and listenin to the rain beat down on that old tin roof like God himself was throwin stones. The gutters was overflowin, water pourin down like some biblical flood meant to wash everything clean. Daddy just sat there starin out into the gray waste of that evenin, his clothes hangin off him like they belonged to some bigger man who'd gone away and left them behind. His hair had gone thin too, like time itself was erasin him bit by bit. Neither of us said nothin about what was comin. Sometimes words just make things more real than they ought to be. I moved my chair closer to his and we both watched the rain fall in the fadin light.

He died in December that year. Five days after I turned twenty-two. They'd pumped him full of poison to kill the thing that was killin him but all it did was make him suffer longer. I lay in my bed at night wonderin what kind of God would do such a thing. I didnt pray. If there was a God up there he'd stopped listenin to folks like us a long time ago.

I didnt go to watch him die. Couldnt. The life that made me was endin and I couldnt bear to see it go. I wanted to remember him like he was that day on the porch, still whole enough to smoke a cigarette and talk about birds. I knew him better than any of them did and he wouldnt have wanted his boy watchin him slip away into whatever darkness was waitin for him. So I curled up in my bed like some wounded animal and waited for word that he was gone.

Nobody even called to tell me when it happened. Like he just disappeared into that gray rain we'd watched together, leaving nothing behind but smoke and memory.

He came in the night to write of John Taylor of Caroline, a man who held fast to the old Republican ways like a drowning man clutches at floating timber. Taylor was a farmer first and foremost and it was the dirt and the growing things that shaped him into what he would become. The land spoke to him of freedom and sovereignty and justice and he listened well.

The new nation lay before him raw and unmolded, like clay waiting for the potter's hands. No ancient customs to bind them, no dead kings' laws to chain their thoughts. Taylor saw in this emptiness a terrible beauty. He knew that the rights of men were like bones in a body, break one and the whole form fails, weaken one and all grow dim. These things must stay beyond the reach of any government's grasp.

He spoke often of man's nature, how it carried both light and dark like twin seeds waiting to sprout. The government must account for both, he said, must be built knowing the truth of what lay in men's hearts. Good principles protect what a man owns, let him work his land, keep the moneylenders at bay. But even good principles cant wash clean what dwells in the souls of those who govern. Self-interest moves in all men like blood in their veins, he said, and its only evil when it feeds off others like a parasite.

The Constitution to Taylor was like scripture that must be read true and careful. He wanted the Federal government small and contained, like a fire in a hearth that warms but doesn't burn the house down. He knew that power and money flow together like twin rivers and both can drown a nation. But words alone weren't enough, he said. You had to know the mind of the men who wrote them. The Declaration was his true north star, showing separate sovereign states instead of one great beast.

He believed in these things with a fervor that burned cold and steady, like stars in a winter sky. The agrarian way was his religion and the land was his church and he preached its gospel until his last breath.

He stood there watching the bowl. Silent. The mind working at it like some broken machine, grinding away at what lay before him but never quite catching hold. Thoughts came and went like ash on the wind. No purchase. No meaning. Just the looking.

Years back hed bought him a book on account of what some artist told him. About drawing with the brain. Right side they called it though he didnt know why. Six years old and wanting to make pictures appear on paper like magic and now here was this book telling how to frame the world. How to section it off from all else. Like taking that bowl of fruit in someones kitchen and making it float there in space. Making it something else entirely.

Standing there now he couldnt find that frame if his life depended on it. Too much. Far too much. He thought about them painters. Picasso with his blues. Monet in his gardens. Them Italian fellows with their colors bright as blood. If he was to make his mark in the world of art this here would be his beginning. His own personal brown period.

His fingers found the handle. Muscles pulled and twisted like something alive down in there. Water moving like glass. Clear and cold. Bits breaking off and floating away to nowhere. Second time harder. More violent. Handle cracking against the porcelain but that brown mass just sat there like something dead. Like something that had never been alive at all.

He stood there in his green tie that choked at his throat. Feet planted like a man about to take a blow. Mop loose in his grip while he studied that thing someone had left there in the Rite Aid toilet. Message written in the oldest language there was. He pulled at the paper. Wrapped his hand like a man wrapping a wound. Drew himself up straight then bent slow at the middle. Hand going down into that water like reaching into hell itself.

They die behind the wheel. Young ones. Not yet grown. The statistics tell their tale in cold numbers writ in blood upon the asphalt. The men in white coats at the National Institute speak of brains not yet ready, synapses still forming in the dark caverns of skull and bone. But there's more to it than that. More than just the rawness of youth and inexperience that sends them careening off the hardtop into darkness.

He'd seen them. Packs of them. Moving through the night in metal coffins, radio sounds bleeding into the darkness. The studies showed it plain as bones bleaching in the sun - more died when they traveled together. The Southern California men had counted the bodies, mapped the correlation between passenger age and metal twisted against concrete barriers.

The state men tried to stem the tide with paper laws. Provisional licenses they called them. Times when the young ones could drive and times when they couldn't. Rules about who could ride beside them in the night. But these were just words on paper, thin as ash.

The truth lay deeper. Cold and hard as winter ground. These children, these drivers barely grown, could not bear the weight of steel and speed. Even at eighteen, said the doctor man Zuckerman, the blood runs too hot. The need for speed and danger burns in them like fever. USA Today printed his words but nobody listened. Nobody wanted to hear that the children of the boom times were coming, millions strong, ready to take the wheel.

The answer was simple as a blade. Keep them from the driver's seat till eighteen years had passed. Let the schools teach them in safety, behind desks and in lots where no blood could flow. Make them wait. Make them learn. Six hours behind the wheel with teachers watching. Fifty more with adults beside them. That's how they did it in California and it could work everywhere if the law men had the guts to make it so.

He thought about the dead ones. How they lay scattered across all the states like fallen leaves. How the numbers kept rising like flood waters in spring. This wasn't new thinking. Others had seen it too. But seeing wasn't enough. Never had been. Never would be.

He sat at the desk studying the papers before him, documents speaking of a thing called Central Auditory Processing Disorder. CAPD they called it. Like the names of dead gods or forgotten machines. Three parts to it there were. The definition and then the diagnosis and then what could be done in the classroom. As if anything could be done. As if anything could be done at all.

The disorder lived in the brain like some dark creature coiled in the deep folds of gray matter. Not in the ears themselves for they worked right enough but in the processing of the sounds themselves. The translation of them. As if the brain spoke one tongue and the ears another and somewhere in between the two languages had been lost. Like pilgrims wandering in some vast cavern with no light to guide them.

They'd found it first in the fifties. Italian doctors with names like prayers. Bocca. Calearo. Cassinari. They'd developed tests for the children who couldn't hear right even though their ears worked fine. Then Kimura came with his dichotic testing. Whatever that was. Whatever that meant in this world or any other.

The signs showed themselves like tracks in ash. A person couldn't tell where sounds came from in the room. Couldn't tell one sound from another or understand when someone's voice changed from serious to mocking. Like being trapped in a world where everything sounded the same. Everything merged together in a gray soup of noise.

To find it they had to test. Audiologists and psychologists watching like prophets of old trying to divine meaning from scattered bones. They'd give questionnaires and watch how people acted when sounds came at them. No single test could catch it. No one knew what caused it. They'd play sounds in both ears at once and ask what was heard. Like some cruel game. More complex tests measured signals in the ear itself but even these weren't certain. Nothing was certain anymore.

He looked up from the papers. Outside the window the world went on as it always had. Uncaring. Indifferent to the struggles of those who couldn't process its sounds properly. He wondered if they would ever truly understand it. If anyone would.

The boy sat on her couch and he knew what the boy was runnin from. Seen it before. The kind of thing that makes the world what it is. Dark and cold and full of them that would do harm to their own blood. He watched the boy's hands shakin and thought about what kind of place this world had become where children flee from their own flesh.

Summer had come and gone since the degree. Psychology. Words on paper that meant nothin when faced with the real darkness in mens souls. The boy had called the law and I went down there to that house. Dark windows like dead eyes watchin. Parents inside with their rehearsed stories and practiced faces. Talkin about simple disputes like evil was just some small thing you could sweep under a rug. Knew right then what I was meant to do in this world.

Social work aint just about helpin. Its about justice. About standin between the darkness and them that cant fight it alone. Seen too many souls crushed trying to fit into what others say they ought to be. Fought against it my whole life. Hair colored like poison flowers and metal in my ears past what folks thought proper. Stood with them that society said weren't right. Gay. Straight. Whatever name they gave themselves. All just souls trying to live in a world that dont want em different.

Watched too many turn away. Too many denied what was real. But the darkness is there whether you look at it or not. Social work. Thats the path. To stand against the tide of pain that flows through families like poison in the blood. To help them that cant help themselves. These are the values burned into me like brands. Service. Respect. Ethics. All just words for doing what's right in a world gone wrong.

Been studyin people long enough to know that evil aint always what you think. Sometimes it wears a smile and makes excuses and calls itself love while it breaks everything it touches. But I know what I seen. Know what needs doin. And I aim to do it.

They called it insomnia but that word was too clean for what it was. Sleep that wouldn't come. Sleep that danced away like smoke in the dark while a man lay watching the ceiling fade from black to gray to black again. The biological and the sociocultural, they said. Words to wrap around the darkness like bandages round a wound that wouldn't heal.

The biological was in the blood and the bone. Inherited like eye color or the shape of a man's hands. Deep in the hypothalamus neurons fired or didn't fire, containing something called orexin that nobody could see but that ruled over sleep and waking like some blind god. GABAB receptors. The words were meaningless but the truth of them was written in the flesh of laboratory mice, poor creatures trapped in mazes of glass and steel while men in white coats watched them dream or fail to dream.

They found that when you stopped these receptors from their firing the mice would sleep. Simple as that. But nothing was ever simple. The sociocultural they called it. The world outside pressing in. School and work and the endless tasks that filled the days. A man who couldn't sleep couldn't work. Couldn't think. Couldn't be what the world demanded.

Sleep disorders came in kinds. Primary disorders and those that rode piggyback on other afflictions of the mind. Dyssomnias they named them, and Parasomnias. More words to wrap around the darkness. Insomnia and hypersomnia. Narcolepsy. Sleep terrors that came in the night like wolves to tear at the mind. Nightmares that left a man sweating in sheets gone cold and damp as cemetery grass.

The truth was in the blood though. In the genes passed down from father to son like dark inheritance. In the neurons firing or not firing in the deep caves of the brain. In the mice dreaming their mouse dreams in laboratories where men sought answers in microscopes and chemical formulas. But answers were like sleep itself. The harder you chased them the faster they ran.

Been here at University Park going on three years now. The getting around weighs heavy. That first year they put me in East Halls, far out as you could go less you counted the stadium standing stark against the gray Pennsylvania sky. The walk from Stuart Hall to classes in Willard, it took near half an hour some days, worse when the weather turned mean like it does in State College, cold and wet and godless.

Talked once with someone who'd walked these grounds before. Said East Halls used to stand alone out there, nothing but empty land stretched between it and civilization like some forsaken outpost. Now sports fields spring up from the earth like grave markers. New buildings too. The Creamery. Health Services. Apartment complexes ring it all like prison walls. Campus grows like some mindless thing, consuming ground, making the distances longer, the walks harder.

What's the answer to all this? The bicycle. Simple as that. But a bicycle alone aint worth nothing without riders and without ground fit for riding.

Met a boy who'd taken back to riding after years away from it. Said he couldn't reckon why he'd ever stopped. "Only way to get around," he said, and there was truth in those words. Bicycle'll take you thirty miles on nothing but a bowl of oatmeal and will. Living off campus now like most who've survived their first year. Bought myself a bike. Best decision I made since coming here. Thomas building's my daily destination, twenty-five minutes walking if you're lucky. On the bike it's five minutes if you're willing to push. Only trouble is Pollock Road. Straightest path there is but it aint friendly to riders nor walkers neither.

Walking's got its merits sure enough but time aint one of them. Without the bike I'd be burning daylight, thirty, forty minutes extra each day just getting to Thomas. That's better than two hours every week lost to nothing but putting one foot before the other. Add in all the other wandering required by this life - classes, meetings, whatever else calls - and you're looking at time you can't afford to lose in this world.

The bike. That's the answer. Simple as that. But nothing's ever really simple, is it?

He sat there in the dim light of his study, turning the pages of Huxley's prophecy. The words stark and cold upon the page like the bones of dead things. In the book there was a world gone wrong. A world where men had forgotten what it was to be men. Where they'd traded their souls for comfort and their minds for pleasure. He knew this truth deep in the marrow of his bones.

The World Controller stood above them all like some dark god. Watching. Always watching. The people below him moved like puppets on strings, dancing to music they couldn't hear, following paths they didn't choose. Each class marked and branded from birth, condemned to their station like prisoners in cells they couldn't see.

They called it conditioning but it was a deeper thing than that. A thing that reached into the very heart of what made a man human and tore it out still beating. The lower classes, the Deltas and Gammas, they moved through their days in a fog of false consciousness, believing the lies whispered into their sleeping minds since before they could walk. Buy, spend, consume. The words like a poison in their blood.

The upper classes weren't much better. Alphas and Betas with their fine clothes and their empty eyes. They knew the truth of their cage but they chose to stay inside it anyway. All except Bernard, who saw the bars for what they were but couldn't break them.

Love was a dead thing in this world. The characters moved past each other like ghosts, never touching, never connecting. The men spoke of women like they were machines, all parts and functions. Pneumatic, they called them. The women talked of coupling like it was nothing more than scratching an itch. No depth to any of them. No soul.

He thought about how the classes stayed in their places, neat and ordered like graves in a cemetery. Each one believing they were better than the rest, while the World Controller watched from above and smiled his cold smile. The people consumed and obeyed and never questioned why, like cattle being led to slaughter but thinking they were going to paradise.

This was Huxley's warning, written in blood and shadow. A world where technology and money had stolen the heart from humanity. Where free will was just another commodity to be bought and sold. Where the individual had been sacrificed on the altar of the community, and no one even remembered what they'd lost.

Four years past I set to learning of Islam at the college. The talk turned always to whether their faith bore violence in its heart. More pressing now than ever it seems, that question.
