Since the towers fell I watched how the papers and screens shifted like wind-blown ash from hatred to a peculiar kind of tolerance. Back then none would have believed a man called Barack Obama, with Muhammadan blood in his line, could seek the highest office in the land.

The Prophet's tale gnaws at me. What's writ of Muhammad stands contrary to what history speaks. I'd known him as a warlord who put the sword to men's throats till they spoke his creed. Yet here in these pages he's rendered a martyr, meek as a lamb, persecuted and patient while folk came to him one by one, drawn to his truth like moths to flame.

There's an echo in these pages that troubles me deep. His miracles mirror Christ's own, most striking when he took mere scraps of meat and milk and made feast enough for forty. The writers craft him thus - humble, seeking no proof of his calling, living quiet in truth and wonder. But this rings false, like thieves who'd steal Christ's crown to set it upon Muhammad's brow.

The book teems with tales meant to witness how men freely chose his way. But these stories come third-hand or worse, passed down like children's whispers - one heard from another who heard from another still. They aimed to prove truth but bred only doubt, like tracks in sand already half-blown away.

What galls most is how they'd paint him gentle and meek, wise and pure of heart. But history tells different tales of blood and iron, and I wonder if his followers today know the true shape of their prophet's rise to power, or if they too are lost in these gentle lies.

The words of the Christ and what he held true in his days were cast off like old rags, abandoned quick as they came. The truth of it stretches out before us like some barren highway leading nowhere, each mile marker showing how far we strayed from where we started. The world now bears witness to something different, something that moves like a slow tide washing away what came before. There are those who cling to the old ways like drowning men to driftwood but they grow fewer, their voices dimmer in the gathering dark.

Among the faithful there's a stirring. A knowing that spreads like fire through dry grass. They'll seek to peel away the layers of man's making, strip bare the bones of belief until nothing remains but what the carpenter from Nazareth brought forth into the world. It might take generations, might take centuries, but sure as winter follows autumn it will come. The great undoing. Like watching time flow backward through some broken clock, doctrine falling away piece by piece until only the raw truth remains, unadorned and pure as the day it was spoken.

When this tide sweeps through the lands of the West like some great cleansing wind, the churches will still stand but they'll be different. Changed. Where once there were a thousand different paths there'll be one. Unity will rise from the ashes of division like some pale phoenix. We've seen such reversals before, seen how the world can turn itself inside out. Rome once fed Christians to lions and then knelt before the cross. Black men went from chains to power. The wheel turns and what was down comes up again.

This great undoing that's coming will need new eyes to read old words. Not taking every utterance as gospel carved in stone but seeing through to the truth beneath, like looking through clear water to the bottom of a stream.

Long ago, before all this, there was only the faith of Abraham. One God, one truth, one holy book. But even then the cracks were showing. Jerusalem under Roman boots split five ways - the Sadducees in their fine robes, Pharisees with their laws, Essenes in the desert, Zealots with their knives, and the common folk caught between them all like leaves in a wind.

The greed runs deep in men's hearts like some ancient poison coursing through their veins. He'd seen it in The Jungle. Seen how they'd turn on their own kind quick as wolves in winter. No care for them below. No thought for the weak ones. Just the wanting and the having and the getting more.

The factory men were the worst of them. Stood in their offices high above the killing floors watching the smoke pour forth from their chimneys like some hell-wrought offering to a darker god. Black smoke stretching out across the land far as eye could see, marking their domain like territorial beasts. Sinclair wrote of them chimneys standing stark against the sky, smoke rivers flowing endless to the world's edge. He knew what it meant. Knew the poison they was putting into the air and earth and water. Didn't matter none to the owners about the folk breathing it or the creatures dying in it.

The workers were less than nothing to them. Just meat for the machine. They'd work a man till his bones showed through his skin then cast him aside like spent cartridges. No loyalty in that place. No decency neither. Just dollars speaking their cold arithmetic. A man's worth measured in pennies and nickels, his life cheaper than the cattle they slaughtered.

Packingtown they called it. Should have called it Hell's Waiting Room. No laws to protect the workers then. No safety neither. Just the endless grind of the machinery and the screaming of the dying beasts and sometimes you couldn't tell which was which. The people lived there like slaves in ancient times, foreign folk mostly, hanging on by threads thin as spider silk. Their masters were worse than any plantation owner, dealing in flesh both living and dead. And in such darkness what blooms but the blackest flowers of man's nature? The unions come but they was jackals too, feeding off the desperation. There was no escape from that place. No salvation. Just the grinding of the great machine eating up souls and spitting out profit.

In the darkened realm where Poe's words take root there lies a poem called Dream-land. He wrote it and called it among his finest works though who can say what drives a man to such proclamations. Within its verses the word Thulé appears like some ancient signpost, twice marked, once at the beginning and again at the end, and scholars say it comes from Virgil who spoke of lands beyond the edge of knowing, north of Britain where the world falls away into darkness and ice.

But there was something else. Something closer. The German writers had gotten hold of Poe's mind and would not let go. Among them stood Goethe whose words burned across the century like signal fires. Arndt saw it plain enough in his studying. Said Poe had taken Goethe's measure and sought to match it stride for stride.

The Oxford books tell of Goethe and his Faust, that great work split in two parts like a cord of wood, the first piece laid down in 1808 and the second not till the year death took him in 1832. And there in the second part lies hidden a darker tale, The King of Thulé. It speaks of a king whose queen passes leaving nothing but a goblet and memories that drink won't wash away. When he can bear it no longer he gives away all he owns save that cup and walks to where the earth ends. Throws it to the sea. Closes his eyes. Dies.

There's something of Poe in that king. Something of the bottle and the grief that drives men to it. The darkness recognizing darkness across the years. Grattan saw it too and made it into theater in 1842, just before Poe took up the word Thulé again in The Pit and the Pendulum.

Thulé appears twice in all Poe's work like twin stars in a black sky. Once in Pit and Pendulum and twice more bracketing Dream-Land like dark sentinels. Read them together, these tales of Thulé, and you'll see the same desolate country. A world drained of color where dead friends walk and loneliness spreads like morning frost. It's as if Poe had stepped into Goethe's kingdom and found it matched the geography of his own heart.

Goethe cast a long shadow in those days. Poe would have known him if only through Tennyson whom he admired with a fire that burned fierce and bright. But there were other paths too, other ways Goethe's words might have found him in those years after Faust first spoke its lines to the world.

The law spoke of malice and despicable deeds but the truth was darker than any words writ upon paper by men in their towers of justice. The store manager sat in his office that evening eating his dinner while outside his door the fluorescent lights hummed their dead song over the aisles where the applesauce lay spilled like some pale blood upon the cold tile floor.

First it was Wayne who came. Wayne with his hollow eyes and his green apron hanging loose like a condemned man's shroud. He spoke of the spill but the manager only stared at his food and said he had no time for such things. Then came Haddigan quarter hour later speaking the same words but they fell dead in that room like birds struck from winter sky.

The woman Palmer she came last. Not knowing. Not seeing. The floor stretched out before her like some treacherous river crossing and when she fell it was as if the earth itself had betrayed her. Her back broke not like a branch but like hope itself. In the year before five others had fallen in that same store their bodies betrayed by the same careless disregard that now claimed Palmer as its latest tribute.

The law spoke of obligations and compensatory damages but these were just words trying to put order to chaos. What mattered was the willful blindness. The conscious turning away. The manager knew what lurked in those aisles having seen five others fall before but still he sat and ate while danger waited patient as death for its next victim.

In the end it would be for the judge to decide if this negligence rose to the level of malice that the law demanded for punitive damages. If this disregard for human safety was despicable enough to warrant special punishment. The evidence lay before them like artifacts from some darker age - the timestamps of warnings ignored the history of falls that came before the simple fact of a man who chose his dinner over his duty to protect those who walked his aisles.

The law would have its say but the truth was already written in Palmer's broken body and in the cold calculations of a man who knew the risks but turned away all the same. There would be no summary dismissal here. The facts themselves stood witness dark and damning as cemetery stones.

The wanting came to her like a thirst that wouldn't quit. Started when she was fourteen and held fast through the years that followed, clinging to her like old shadows in dying light. By seventeen it had shaped itself into something else. Not a thing but a someone. The boys came and went, awkward in their pursuit, fumbling at romance like blind men at locks. None took. She studied this peculiarity in herself like reading old maps, searching for landmarks that weren't there, finding only the blank spaces where answers ought to be. So she walked on through her days carrying this thing that had no name.

The house stood quiet most days. Her people were peaceful folk who moved through rooms like ghosts, their voices soft as ash falling. Arguments were rare as rain in drought lands, save when the girl's wild spirit rose up against their quietude. She carried something fierce and bright in her that stood at odds with their stillness, yet folk were drawn to her like moths to flame.

Then came the day when peace broke. She was moving room to room, restless as wind, when her mother's cry split the air like lightning. Kitchen-ways. She ran, calling out, her heart a hammer in her chest. Found her mother laid out on the tile like something broken. Pain had hold of her and wouldn't let go. The girl knelt beside her, hands hovering uncertain. Mother's words came broken and scattered: hospital, hurry, help. The girl, strong from years of working iron, lifted her mother like a child. Carried her to the waiting car, laid her gentle in the back, and drove through streets empty as dead riverbeds.

The hospital rose up before them like some concrete monument to suffering. Inside, the air hung thick with antiseptic and fear, but the girl noticed none of it, her world narrowed to her mother's pain. She called out and white-coated figures appeared like pale wraiths, wheeling out a stretcher. They took her mother away down corridors bright and merciless as desert sun, leaving the girl alone with her worry.

Later they told her: a step-stool, a high cabinet, a vase. Simple things that conspired to bring her mother low. She sat and waited in that place of sickness and healing, watching shadows lengthen across walls white as bone.

They studied the old ways of eating. The Mediterranean way. Not like the others but something darker and more ancient. Something that spoke to the blood and the heart. In the beginning there were seventy four thousand eight hundred and eighty six women. Nurses all of them. They had no heart disease nor the sugar sickness that plagues mankind. The researchers watched them for twenty years like patient sentinels marking the passage of time and death itself.

The women wrote down what they ate. Six times over those long years they wrote it all down. What passed their lips and into their bodies. The fruits and the nuts and the grains ground to dust. Fish from the deep waters. The researchers made numbers of these things. Scores they called them. Like marking the passage of the dead but these marked the living.

Some ate like the old ones did. The Mediterranean people. Others did not. The researchers watched and waited. Death came as it always does. Two thousand three hundred and ninety one hearts failed. One thousand seven hundred and sixty three minds were starved of blood till they died. The numbers told a story as old as time. Those who ate like the ancients lived longer. Their hearts were stronger. Their blood flowed true.

They measured everything. The weight of their bodies. The smoke in their lungs. The pills they took to thin their blood. Whether they bore children still or had ceased. Whether they moved their bodies under the sun or sat idle. All of it marked down in ledgers like a careful accounting of souls.

In the end the numbers spoke clear as bones in the desert. Those who followed the old ways, who ate the fruits of the earth and the fish of the sea, they lived. Their hearts beat longer. Their minds stayed clear. The others died sooner, their bodies betraying them like false prophets in the night. Such is the way of things. Such is the price we pay for forgetting the old wisdom that lives in our blood.

The cardboard sign hung there in the gray light. Hitler is alive in Burma. The girl held it above her head like some proclamation of doom, standing alone on that corner where the wind swept ash and old newspapers across the blacktop. She'd been in pictures. Movies that no one would watch anymore.

Burma. Myanmar. Names dont matter now. The junta rose up in 62 like some biblical plague visited upon the people. A darkness. Soldiers with their rifles and their tanks moving through streets where monks in saffron robes walked barefoot carrying nothing but their bowls. The first protests in ten years. Ten years of silence broken by gunfire and screaming and the sound of monastery doors being kicked in. They came for the foreign journalists too. Rounded them up like cattle. Shot them where they stood. A Japanese man named Nagai lay dead in the street on September 27th, his camera still clicking away at nothing as his lifeblood ran into the gutters.

Thirteen dead they said. Colonel Win knew better. He'd seen the bodies stacked like cordwood behind the barracks. Several thousand he said. Several thousand souls crying out in the void.

These things were nothing new. They'd happened before and they'd happen again. The Romans had done it. The Japanese. Now these generals with their medals and their decorated uniforms stained with the blood of their own people. Man has always killed man. Has always found reason to do so. Even now somewhere in the world someone was dying because someone else had decided they should.

Tiananmen Square stood as testament. The tanks rolling through the streets crushing the bones of students and workers alike. Two hundred dead said the government. Three thousand said the Red Cross. The truth lay somewhere in between or perhaps beyond both. In Rwanda they killed with machetes. Neighbor against neighbor. Hutu against Tutsi. The streets ran red. And before that there was Hitler. The camps. The chambers. The ovens burning day and night. The ash falling like gray snow. All of it written in the blood of millions. All of it carried in the wind like some dark promise. Some covenant with death that man had made long ago and could not break.

The girl stood there holding her sign. A witness to things she could not change. To horrors beyond counting. The wind took her hair and whipped it about her face like black smoke. Like a veil. Like something mourning all of mankind.

The old maestro's mark on the music they called jazz came from the long years he spent wielding that orchestra like some dark instrument of God. His hands moved across them ivory keys quiet as a thief in the night but it was in the writing of the music that his true power lay dormant waiting to strike. He knew each man in that band like a father knows his sons and he wrote for their souls not just their horns. He'd craft these pieces like some old world artificer building frameworks of brass and wood and gut string where them soloists could roam free as wild horses on the plain. But he could reign them in too when he needed with notes precise as prison bars.

The sound. Always the sound. He shaped it like a sculptor shapes clay, knew just how to bend it and mold it till it fit right in the ear like it was always meant to be there. Weren't no accident neither. He studied them players like a hunter studies prey, learned the way each one moved and breathed and when he put them all together it was like watching some great machine come to life, all the gears and wheels turning just so.

Take that piece they called Creole Love Call. Six parts to it like the chambers in a revolver and each one loaded different. First comes the voice pure as spring water then turning dark and rough like creek water after rain. Then a trumpet crying out through a mute like some wounded animal in the night. High clarinet floating over it all like a ghost while the piano keeps time below quiet as footsteps in sand. The whole band rises up then like a storm coming, brass and reeds calling back and forth across the darkness till finally that voice returns growling like some creature that aint quite human no more.

He wrote another one called Hot and Bothered where he took Miley's trumpet and Cox's voice and made them dance together like they was kin. Then there was It Don't Mean a Thing where old Tricky Sam's trombone spoke the first words like some preacher starting up a sermon. Each piece different but carrying that same dark blood in its veins. That was the old man's gift. He could make music speak in tongues that wasn't meant for speaking at all.

He sat there studying the shells. Ancient things. Spiraled and calcified testimonies to lives long past. The question that gnawed at him was how these creatures came to be what they were, what forces shaped them in the darkness of deep time. Back in 1917 a man named Thompson had written that science hadn't yet found the mathematics to describe even the simplest living things. Truth was, they still hadn't.

The shell lay before him on the scarred wooden table. Prunum, they called it. He turned it in his fingers, watching how the light played across its surface. They'd taken X-rays of hundreds of these things, feeding numbers into machines that could birth ghost-shells, theoretical forms that might have been or might yet be. The computer program was called CerioShell, though names meant little now.

He thought about how a shell grows. Like a living geometry, a spiral road through time and space. Three hundred and sixty degrees of pure mathematics, though there was nothing pure about it. The whorls, that's what they called the turns, spinning around an invisible axis they named columella, though it was really just the spine of the thing. Each whorl separated by a line they called a suture, like stitches holding the whole thing together.

The biggest part, the body whorl, that's where the creature made its last stand before death took it. Above that, the spire rose like a tower of previous lives, previous moments, all the way to the apex. At the bottom, the base. And there in the opening, the aperture, that's where life once crept in and out, conducting its business with the world.

You could look at these things from any angle. From above, from below, from the front where the creature once emerged. He'd learned to count the whorls, drawing lines across the shell's face like measuring time itself, quarter turn by quarter turn, marking the slow accretion of calcium and purpose.

He thought about how each shell was really just a series of doorways, each aperture a frozen moment in the creature's journey through time. You could trace it, map it, try to capture it in numbers and equations. But in the end, it was all just guesswork at God's geometry, trying to understand why things grew the way they did, why life chose the paths it chose.

The mathematics of it all lay there like a dead language, waiting to be resurrected. But even then, even if you could speak it perfectly, you'd still just be describing shadows on a cave wall, not the thing itself. Not the force that drove it all.

They stood there in the dim light of the government office studying the numbers on the wall. Charts and figures that told of dead children. Ten years worth of them laid out in cold statistics that hadnt changed. Numbers that spoke of mothers too. The boy looked up at him. What does it mean papa.

It means they're dying son. Same as they always did.

In the cities and in the villages they died. The lucky ones had someone there. Someone who knew the old ways of bringing life into the world. But knowledge aint always enough. When the blood comes. When things go wrong. They called them midwives but they might as well have been ghosts for all the good they could do when death came calling.

He remembered the hospital in Jakarta. Clean white walls and machines that beeped in the night. Seven of every hundred mothers got their babies cut from them there. In the villages it was two. Numbers that told a story of who lived and who died based on nothing more than where they drew their first breath.

The poor died more. Always had. Twenty-seven percent more of them never saw inside a hospital than the rich. Money was the difference between life and death and it always had been. Some things dont change even when the world tries to make them change.

They talked about programs. About targeting specific problems like a hunter sighting down a rifle barrel. Quick fixes and immediate results that looked good on paper. But he knew better. Had seen what happened when you built one thing up while letting everything else crumble. Like trying to prop up one wall of a burning house. The whole thing would come down eventually. Always did.

He looked at the boy again. The boy was studying the charts with those solemn eyes of his. Papa, he said. Why dont they fix all of it.

Because son. Sometimes the simplest answer is the hardest one to see.

The music they called Popular had growed and spread like some dark vine across a hundred years til a man couldnt name all its branches anymore. Each limb of it birthing new ones. Rap and rock and country and jazz and folk and others nameless and strange. Like some ancient tree whose roots ran deep into the black soil of time. And from these roots come Heavy Metal, forty years past, spreading like wildfire through the musical wasteland. A thing built of darkness and rage but containing multitudes. Raw emotions stripped bare and bleeding. Men saw its power and took to shaping it like hot iron, hammering out new forms til the original shape was lost to memory.

Now the metal stands transformed, a thousand faces staring back from the dark. A thing that feeds on other music like some desperate creature, taking what it needs, leaving the rest to rot. To know its true nature you got to go back. Back to where it began. Back to understand why they call it a movement and not just music.

Metal dwells in darkness like some cave-thing. Always wanting more. More thunder in the bass, more violence in the sound, more theater in the spectacle. These weren't no primitive players neither. These were men who knew their tools like a hunter knows his knife. And there was the drugs too, coursing through it all like poison in the blood. Mid-seventies when the psychedelics hit hard and the music turned strange and otherworldly, like something born in fever dreams. It carried things in it that other music wouldn't touch. Dark things. Visceral things. Things that reached back to them old Romantic composers who knew about darkness too. The kind of darkness that makes a man write words like these here below, though the paper they was writ on is long since ashes.

Them Beatles, they wrote Helter Skelter trying to outdo the Stones. Show em they could walk in darkness too. Some say it was the first real Metal song, though such things aint easy to reckon. A song about going up and down, about losing your mind to them pills and powders. They put it on that white album like a black mark on a clean sheet.

In the time before the dreamers came with their wild paintings there was another who walked alone. Rousseau was his name and he crafted visions that came to him in the deep of night, both real and imagined. The Dream they called it, this thing he made in 1910, and in it lay not just some woman lost in wonderment at the strange country round her but Rousseau's own yearnings that gnawed at him like hunger. Recognition he sought. Acceptance too. These things burned in him while he walked the path between what others wanted and what his hands knew to do.

He was born in a place called Laval where the wind comes hard off the northwest coast of France. His father worked metal and sold hardware and they didnt starve. No teachers showed him the way of art. He worked for the government collecting tolls till he was forty years gone from his birth, though some called him customs man which he wasnt. His first wife Clémence died after watching eight babies go into the ground. Only Julia lived. The grief sat in him like stone and he took up the brush hoping it might wash clean what was stained.

He painted different from the others who made pretty pictures of country folk. He painted true because he was of them. Common blood. Common dreams.

The art world was a beast he could not tame. Started late with no learning and worked alongside men who'd mastered the craft in their youth. Matisse was rising then, but they were different sorts entirely. Matisse feared the common way of painting like it was death itself while Rousseau wanted nothing more than to make something so right and proper that the Artiste Français would open their doors to him. But doors dont open easy to men who walk alone.

He sat there thinking on them things that men before him had thought on. Ethics and beauty and how they was bound together like flesh to bone. Old Keats had wrote it down plain as day on that grecian urn of his. Beauty is truth and truth beauty and that was all there was to know in this world. Most everything a man learns comes by way of books or hard living but these things was different. Like they was already there waiting to be found.

He thought on how describing beauty or goodness was like trying to catch smoke in your hands. You could talk about the Mona Lisa's shadows or the way the background stretched away behind her like something from a fever dream but that wasnt it. That wasnt what made it beautiful. Folk would always say there was just something about it before they started in with their fancy talk. Like they knew the words wasnt enough.

He remembered what that woman O'Connor had said about stories. How they was meant to say things that couldn't be said no other way. Like they was carrying something bigger than words. Something that lived in the spaces between em. And he reckoned it was the same with right and wrong. That writer Wittgenstein knew it too. Said ethics couldn't be spoke of proper cause they was beyond speaking.

The connection twixt the two of them, art and morals, it lived in that place you couldn't quite reach. Like trying to remember a dream that slips away soon as you wake. The deeper truth of it all existed somewhere past what a man could put into words. Literature carried it strongest of all the arts cause it dealt in the currency of life itself. Values and choices and the hard paths men walk. The things that make us human in this godless world.

He watched the sun sink below the horizon, painting the sky in colors that no artist could capture. Thought about how some truths cant be spoke, only felt in the marrow of your bones. How beauty and goodness was like that. Beyond telling. Beyond knowing. Just there, waiting to be found by them that had eyes to see.

The land lay ancient and cold beneath the alpine shadows stretching north like some great beast's spine from München to the dark waters of the Baltic where Kiel stood sentinel against the gray horizon. The old ways persisted here like blood in the earth, seeping through the stones of Köln where the Rhine carved its path and eastward through Saxon country where Dresden brooded by the Elbe's sluggish waters. This was Germania.

They called it different names in the old tongue. Some said it came from the Tungrians, fierce warriors who crossed the Rhine in times before memory, when the world was younger and the gods walked closer to men. Caesar knew them. Wrote of them in his accounts of blood and conquest, marking them separate from the Gauls he'd broken beneath Rome's heel. The Germans remained untamed, wild things that lurked beyond the river's far bank, emerging in the night with spears they called ger, their war-cries splitting the darkness like thunder.

Tacitus wrote of them too, scratching his observations onto parchment while Rome's streets baked under Mediterranean sun. He saw them as creatures of the soil, born from the earth itself, unmixed with foreign blood. Who would choose such a place, he wondered. Who would abandon warm southern climes for this raw country with its sullen skies and forests that whispered old secrets in tongues no Roman could comprehend.

The Romans came nonetheless, drawn by amber and fur and things that glittered in the ground. They built their roads and fortresses but never stayed, always returning to their marble columns and heated baths, leaving Germania to its shadows. The tribes remained, trading their forest-wealth for Roman coin, sending their young men to march beneath imperial eagles while their true gods waited patient in the deep woods, knowing Rome's time would pass like all things must, while Germania endured, eternal as the stones.

The play stretches out before us like some ancient tapestry gone yellow with age, threads bare in places where time has gnawed at the fabric. Deception lies at its heart, a dark and necessary thing, like a knife kept ready against the wolves. But there is a cost to wearing masks and the soul knows this cost even if the mind does not. The self becomes a stranger in its own skin and must one day choose between preservation and the bonds that tie it to others. Some will forgive the lie. Others will carry it like a wound that never heals.

When the mask is one of gender it cuts deeper still. The question hangs in the air like smoke - why would one abandon the shelter of their own flesh? For Viola it was survival pure and simple. The words fall from her lips like stones: "I'll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count..." She speaks of preservation but what is preserved is merely the body while the spirit wanders lost in the wilderness of pretense.

The deception works its dark magic but leaves her cut off from her own kind, adrift in a world of women who cannot know her. And Olivia, poor Olivia, sees in her the ghost of Sebastian and loves what is not there: "Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay." The words echo hollow in the empty air. Even Orsino carries the weight of unspoken desire: "Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me."

To modern eyes the play might seem to speak of hidden hungers, of desires that dare not speak their names. Olivia and Orsino move through their scenes like sleepwalkers, their true hearts masked even from themselves. But perhaps Shakespeare saw deeper still, saw how Olivia's quick transfer of affection from Cesario to Sebastian marked her as one who loved with her eyes alone, as if the heart could be fooled by mere appearance. At the last she names Viola sister - "A sister, you are she" - and in those words lies both acceptance and forgiveness, as if the truth, once spoken, could wash clean all that came before.

They called it German rule but there was nothing German about the blood. Blood speaks its own tongue and the Herero and Nama knew it well when the Germans came with their rifles and their orders and their need to plant flags in foreign soil. The land remembered. The land always remembers.

In the east they built schools. Built them like they meant something. Like knowledge could bridge what guns had sundered. The British found them there when they came. Found the africans who could read and write and cipher numbers. Found them in Tanganyika and in Kamerun too. But in the southwest there was nothing. Nothing but missionaries wandering like pilgrims through the wasteland spreading their word to empty air while the government watched and did nothing.

The whites got their schools though. Got them built proper with government coin. Got their children taught proper too while the natives watched from beyond the windows, their faces pressed against glass that showed them nothing but their own reflection. Most never learned to read. Most never learned to write. Most just learned to survive.

The southwest was different. Different in ways that spoke of deeper things. Of older things. Things that lived in the hearts of men who came to plant their flags and spread their seed. By 1913 they numbered fifteen thousand strong. White faces in a brown land. More than anywhere else in all their conquered realm. The climate suited them they said. Not too hot. Not too cold. Just right for making something of their own. Something that would last.

But the land remembered. The land always remembers.

They wrote about it later. Wrote about it in German first then English. Wrote about how different it was from place to place. Territory to territory. How the schools worked here but not there. How the teaching took root in some soil but not in others. They had their reasons. Their explanations. Their theories written in neat lines on clean paper. But paper burns and ink fades and in the end there is only the land and what it remembers.

They stood at the border, these two nations, like ancient beasts eyeing each other across a divide that stretched fifty-seven years deep into time. From 1836 to 1893 they circled and prowled, the United States and Mexico, their rivalry carved into the very bones of the earth. The war came in 1846 like some dark tide rising, Americans moving south with their rifles and their god, taking Texas and the Southwest territories in blood and dust and gunsmoke.

The border between them was a thing alive, a serpentine line drawn in sand and stone where cultures ground against each other like tectonic plates. Religion stood between them like a wall. Protestant and Catholic, each carrying the ghosts of old world hatreds in their veins, the English and Spanish dead whispering ancient grievances into living ears.

Seventeen times they clashed in those years, most often over the borderlands where outlaws and brigands moved like wraiths through the desert night. Raiders crossed back and forth, leaving destruction in their wake until both nations sent their armies to stand watch in the wastes. The border towns existed in a kind of twilight, neither here nor there, where a man might wake to find himself in one country or another depending on which way the wind had blown the sand that night.

The rivalry was a living thing until it wasn't. Like some great beast lying down to die, it faded as Mexico grew dependent on its northern neighbor. The United States no longer looked to the land with hungry eyes but turned its gaze to money and markets. The old hatreds didn't die but transformed, became something else, something that could be counted in ledgers instead of bodies.

They share that border still, these two nations, though the nature of their dance has changed. The ghosts of old conflicts walk those lands yet, their footprints hidden beneath the shifting sands of time, waiting for those who know where to look. In the end it was not god or guns that bridged the divide but the cold arithmetic of commerce, turning blood-soaked earth into columns of numbers, transforming ancient enmity into profit and loss.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like most afflictions but sudden and complete, like a door slamming shut in the dark. I didn't even know such a thing existed until it had me in its grip.

I was a nurse then. Chose it out of some deep hollow need for safety that came from having none as a child. They'd all say it - you'll always find work, folk'll always be sick and dying. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up with the healing trade though it wasn't what my heart wanted.

Then there I was. Forty-six years lived and alone, nothing saved, and the work gone from me like smoke. Still am broken, these fifteen years later. Living on government handouts has stripped me bare. Everything I once called mine is gone now. Each day's a battle against the void, against the feeling of being less than whole. Nothing's certain anymore except one truth that burns like a coal in the dark - I wouldn't have survived without my people. Family. The few friends who stayed. When the real darkness comes you learn quick how weak you really are.

That's the thing about catastrophe. It comes without warning. No matter how you shore up against it, some storms are too big to weather alone. Like them old pioneers crossing the mountains. Conservatives preach about going it alone but that ain't how the wagons made it west. It was sharing. Looking out. Helping hands in the night.

So yes, lay in your stores. I got mine - medical supplies, water tablets, tape for the windows against whatever poison might come on the wind. Flashlights. Batteries. Candles and matches sealed against damp. Canned goods lined up like soldiers. Plant your garden if you got the land. Stack your wood if you got a stove to burn it.

But while you're preparing for the end of things, know your neighbors. Because when the real darkness comes, it ain't rugged independence that'll save us. It's the light we keep burning for each other.

In the old world, before the steel and concrete rose up to mock the heavens, there lived a prince. They would later call him Buddha though that wasnt his name then. None knew what would come. He cast off the gilded chains of his station like a snake shedding its skin and walked into the wastes of the world until enlightenment found him or he found it, who could say. What he taught became Buddhism and the Theravada sect claimed to hold closest to his words, though who could know after twenty five hundred years of men's tongues wagging and their minds forgetting.

In Sri Lanka they cut the water now. Some ceremony the Buddha never spoke of. Monks in their saffron robes and the common folk too, gathering like pilgrims at some ancient well. The faith had changed like everything changes, wearing smooth like river stones beneath the endless flow of time. The guardians of the old ways, both robed and common, had bent like reeds in the wind, doctrine twisting and reshaping itself against forces from within and without. Some came with fire and sword, others with mere indifference, each leaving their mark like the tide leaves its mark upon the shore.

They spoke of internal forces and external ones as if such things could be parsed clean like butchered meat. Internal meant those who claimed the Buddha's way as their own, external meant all others though such divisions meant little in the end. Then there were those who came meaning harm and those who meant nothing at all, though harm or help might follow in their wake like carrion birds following a war party.

At the heart of it lay the triple gem they sought refuge in: Buddha, Dhamma, Sangha. The Dhamma held in three baskets of ancient words: the Suttas with their teachings, the Vinaya with its rules, the Abhidhamma with its truths about the nature of things. They spoke of Anatta - the absence of soul, Dukkha - the suffering that clings to life like smoke to clothing, Anicca - how nothing lasts, nothing stays, everything crumbles to dust in time. Only by seeing these truths could one break free from Sansara, that wheel of death and rebirth grinding on and on like some cosmic mill wheel. Then would end the holy trinity of man's afflictions: desire, hatred, delusion. The rules came after, five for common folk - no killing, no lying, no stealing, no rutting like beasts, no drowning sense in drink or smoke. More rules for the monks, though rules were just words and words were wind.

Four noble truths stood at the center like stone pillars in a temple: that life was suffering, that wanting caused the suffering, that suffering could end. These were the bones everything else was built upon.
